nodes.label: Ava
nodes.source_span: Patient: I’ve had a nagging cough for about a week.

nodes.label: Mild asthma exacerbation
nodes.source_span: Doctor: Given the cough and wheeze after a likely viral trigger, this looks like a mild asthma flare.

nodes.label: Albuterol
nodes.source_span: Patient: I use an albuterol inhaler—two puffs when I’m tight.

nodes.label: Azithromycin

attributes.frequency: two tablets day 1, then one daily days 2–5

nodes.source_span: If bacterial features develop, start azithromycin 250 mg...

nodes.label: Anaphylaxis to penicillin
nodes.source_span: Patient: I had an anaphylaxis reaction years ago.

nodes.label: Mild expiratory wheeze
nodes.source_span: On exam your lungs have a mild expiratory wheeze.

nodes.label: Assessment of asthma exacerbation
nodes.source_span: Assessment and Plan: Mild asthma exacerbation with nocturnal symptoms following recent viral exposure.

nodes.label: Potential for bacterial bronchitis
nodes.source_span: if signs of bacterial bronchitis emerge...

nodes.label: Generalizability issues
nodes.source_span: Doctor: Given the cough and wheeze after a likely viral trigger...

nodes.label: Unmeasured confounders
nodes.source_span: Patient: My son had a cold last week.

nodes.label: Sustainability concerns
nodes.source_span: consider controller if symptoms persist >2 weeks.

nodes.label: Selection biases
nodes.source_span: Doctor: Given the cough and wheeze...

nodes.label: Data quality issues
nodes.source_span: Assessment and Plan: Mild asthma exacerbation...

summary: The patient, Ava, is experiencing a mild asthma exacerbation treated with an albuterol inhaler and potential azithromycin if bacterial bronchitis develops. Key assumptions include the potential for unmeasured confounders and generalizability issues regarding the treatment's effectiveness across different populations.
